channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07656-x

Retraction Note: Microbiome analyses of blood and tissues suggest cancer diagnostic approach
item.dc:title: Retraction Note: Microbiome analyses of blood and tissues suggest cancer diagnostic approach

Mechanism for the initiation of spliceosome disassembly

Buried interface molecular hybrid for inverted perovskite solar cells

item.title: Aged mice regain youthful muscles thanks to a compound that acts on the genes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02100-6

A molecule increases levels of a protein that maintains telomeres, the caps on the ends of chromosomes.
item.dc:title: Aged mice regain youthful muscles thanks to a compound that acts on the genes

item.title: Freudian scripts and sensory slips: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02084-3

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Freudian scripts and sensory slips: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Digging deep for India’s water solution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02087-0

Vishwanath Srikantaiah works to restore India’s historic wells to provide better protection for water resources.
item.dc:title: Digging deep for India’s water solution
item.dc:creator: Alexia Austin

item.title: Chemical reservoir computation in a self-organizing reaction network
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07567-x

A chemical reservoir computer based on the formose reaction has been discovered that can perform several nonlinear classification tasks in parallel, predict the dynamics of other complex systems and achieve time-series forecasting.
item.dc:title: Chemical reservoir computation in a self-organizing reaction network
item.dc:creator: Mathieu G. Baltussen
Thijs J. de Jong
Quentin Duez
William E. Robinson
Wilhelm T. S. Huck

item.title: Molecular basis for transposase activation by a dedicated AAA+ ATPase
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07550-6

Solution and cryogenic electron microscopy studies using IS21 as a model transposase system show how AAA+ ATPases induce structural changes to prime target DNA and activate their associated transposases.
item.dc:title: Molecular basis for transposase activation by a dedicated AAA+ ATPase
item.dc:creator: Álvaro de la Gándara
Mercedes Spínola-Amilibia
Lidia Araújo-Bazán
Rafael Núñez-Ramírez
James M. Berger
Ernesto Arias-Palomo

item.title: Zinc mediates control of nitrogen fixation via transcription factor filamentation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07607-6

Zinc acts as a second messenger in root nodules and regulates nitrogen homeostasis by controlling the transition between the active state and the inactive filamentous state of the novel transcriptional regulator FIXATION UNDER NITRATE (FUN).
item.dc:title: Zinc mediates control of nitrogen fixation via transcription factor filamentation
item.dc:creator: Jieshun Lin
Peter K. Bjørk
Marie V. Kolte
Emil Poulsen

Dugald Reid

item.title: TnpB homologues exapted from transposons are RNA-guided transcription factors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07598-4

RNA-guided transcription factors arose repeatedly via the domestication of transposon-encoded tnpB genes, representing a parallel evolutionary path to CRISPR-Cas adaptive immunity.
item.dc:title: TnpB homologues exapted from transposons are RNA-guided transcription factors
item.dc:creator: Tanner Wiegand
Florian T. Hoffmann
Matt W. G. Walker
Stephen Tang
Egill Richard
Hoang C. Le
Chance Meers
Samuel H. Sternberg

item.title: Explainable El Niño predictability from climate mode interactions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07534-6

An extended nonlinear recharge oscillator model shows skilful and explainable El Niño–Southern Oscillation forecasts at lead times up to 16–18 months, better than global climate models and comparable to the most skilful artificial intelligence forecasts.
item.dc:title: Explainable El Niño predictability from climate mode interactions
item.dc:creator: Sen Zhao
Fei-Fei Jin
Malte F. Stuecker
Philip R. Thompson
Jong-Seong Kug
Michael J. McPhaden
Mark A. Cane
Andrew T. Wittenberg
Wenju Cai

item.title: Cenozoic history of the tropical marine biodiversity hotspot
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07617-4

A reconstruction of Cenozoic marine biodiversity in the Indo-Australian Archipelago reveals decreasing rates of net diversification and identifies the factors that have established it as the richest marine biodiversity hotspot.
item.dc:title: Cenozoic history of the tropical marine biodiversity hotspot
item.dc:creator: Skye Yunshu Tian
Moriaki Yasuhara

item.title: Titanium:sapphire-on-insulator integrated lasers and amplifiers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07457-2

A photonic platform enables miniaturization and scalability of titanium:sapphire photonic technology, reducing footprint and cost by three orders of magnitude.
item.dc:title: Titanium:sapphire-on-insulator integrated lasers and amplifiers
item.dc:creator: Joshua Yang
Kasper Van Gasse
Daniil M. Lukin
Melissa A. Guidry
Geun Ho Ahn
Alexander D. White
Jelena Vučković

item.title: Synaptic architecture of leg and wing premotor control networks in Drosophila
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07600-z

We use connectomics to compare the wiring logic of premotor circuits controlling the Drosophila leg and wing, finding that both premotor networks cluster into modules that link motor neurons innervating muscles with related functions.
item.dc:title: Synaptic architecture of leg and wing premotor control networks in Drosophila
item.dc:creator: Ellen Lesser

item.title: Megastudy shows that reminders boost vaccination but adding free rides does not
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07591-x

Contrary to expectations, offers of free transportation to vaccine sites did not increase COVID-19 vaccine uptake more than text message reminders, a finding that has implications for future policy decision-making to promote vaccination.
item.dc:title: Megastudy shows that reminders boost vaccination but adding free rides does not
item.dc:creator: Katherine L. Milkman

item.title: Connectomic reconstruction of a female Drosophila ventral nerve cord
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07389-x

Automated reconstruction of dense neural networks in the ventral nerve cord of the fruit fly provides a resource for investigating the neural control of movement.
item.dc:title: Connectomic reconstruction of a female Drosophila ventral nerve cord

item.title: Structural mechanism of bridge RNA-guided recombination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07570-2

Using cryo-electron microscopy, the structural mechanism by which non-coding bridge RNA confers target and donor DNA specificity to IS110 recombinases for programmable DNA recombination is explored.
item.dc:title: Structural mechanism of bridge RNA-guided recombination
item.dc:creator: Masahiro Hiraizumi

Hiroshi Nishimasu

item.title: Experimental observation of repulsively bound magnons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07599-3

Comparison of terahertz spectroscopy measurements with theoretical results for the Heisenberg–Ising chain antiferromagnet demonstrates the existence of repulsively bound magnons in large transverse fields below the quantum critical point.
item.dc:title: Experimental observation of repulsively bound magnons
item.dc:creator: Zhe Wang
Catalin-Mihai Halati
Jean-Sébastien Bernier
Alexey Ponomaryov
Denis I. Gorbunov
Sandra Niesen
Oliver Breunig
J. Michael Klopf
Sergei Zvyagin
Thomas Lorenz
Alois Loidl
Corinna Kollath

item.title: An intermediate Rb–E2F activity state safeguards proliferation commitment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07554-2

Cells actively sense external and internal signals to stay quiescent or proliferate, and this trigger relies on being in a reversible primed G1 state of partial retinoblastoma inactivation and E2F activation.
item.dc:title: An intermediate Rb–E2F activity state safeguards proliferation commitment
item.dc:creator: Yumi Konagaya
David Rosenthal
Nalin Ratnayeke
Yilin Fan
Tobias Meyer

item.title: Hotspot shelters stimulate frog resistance to chytridiomycosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07582-y

Artificial thermal refugia—sites heated to temperatures higher than that of the surrounding environment—provide a way to protect an endangered Australian frog species from a fungal disease that has caused the extinction of many amphibians.
item.dc:title: Hotspot shelters stimulate frog resistance to chytridiomycosis
item.dc:creator: Anthony W. Waddle
Simon Clulow
Amy Aquilina
Erin L. Sauer
Shannon W. Kaiser
Claire Miller

Richard Shine

item.title: Measuring gravitational attraction with a lattice atom interferometer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07561-3

Using an optical lattice to suspend atoms, the gravitational attraction of a miniature source mass can be determined by an atom interferometer with much greater accuracy compared with atoms in free fall.
item.dc:title: Measuring gravitational attraction with a lattice atom interferometer
item.dc:creator: Cristian D. Panda
Matthew J. Tao
Miguel Ceja
Justin Khoury
Guglielmo M. Tino
Holger Müller

item.title: Unconventional superconductivity in chiral molecule–TaS<sub>2</sub> hybrid superlattices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07625-4

By incorporating chiral molecules into conventional superconductor lattices such as TaS2 to form a hybrid superlattice, non-centrosymmetry could be introduced and can be shown to help lead to unconventional superconductivity.
item.dc:title: Unconventional superconductivity in chiral molecule–TaS<sub>2</sub> hybrid superlattices
item.dc:creator: Zhong Wan
Gang Qiu
Huaying Ren
Qi Qian
Yaochen Li

Yu Huang

Xiangfeng Duan

item.title: Brain Chimeroids reveal individual susceptibility to neurotoxic triggers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07578-8

An analysis in 3D multidonor Chimeroids—a scalable multidonor human brain organoid model—shows that human genetic background may be an important mediator of neurotoxin susceptibility.
item.dc:title: Brain Chimeroids reveal individual susceptibility to neurotoxic triggers
item.dc:creator: Noelia Antón-Bolaños
Irene Faravelli
Tyler Faits
Sophia Andreadis

item.title: Transposase-assisted target-site integration for efficient plant genome engineering
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07613-8

Fusion of rice Pong transposase to the Cas9 or Cas12a programmable nucleases provides sequence-specific targeted insertion of enhancer elements, an open reading frame and gene expression cassette into the genome of the model plant Arabidopsis and crop soybean.
item.dc:title: Transposase-assisted target-site integration for efficient plant genome engineering
item.dc:creator: Peng Liu
Kaushik Panda

R. Keith Slotkin

item.title: Bridge RNAs direct programmable recombination of target and donor DNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07552-4

A bispecific non-coding RNA expressed by the IS110 family of mobile genetic elements forms the basis of a programmable genome-editing system that enables the insertion, excision or inversion of specific target DNA sequences.
item.dc:title: Bridge RNAs direct programmable recombination of target and donor DNA
item.dc:creator: Matthew G. Durrant
Nicholas T. Perry
James J. Pai
Aditya R. Jangid

item.title: Oxylipins and metabolites from pyroptotic cells act as promoters of tissue repair
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07585-9

Defining the composition of the secretome of pyroptotic macrophages reveals the involvement of the component factors in wound healing.
item.dc:title: Oxylipins and metabolites from pyroptotic cells act as promoters of tissue repair
item.dc:creator: Parul Mehrotra
Sophia Maschalidi

item.title: Drosophila immune cells transport oxygen through PPO2 protein phase transition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07583-x

Drosophila haemocytes collaborate with the tracheal system to reserve and transport oxygen through the phase transition of PPO2 crystals, facilitating internal oxygen homeostasis in a process that is comparable to vertebrate respiration.
item.dc:title: Drosophila immune cells transport oxygen through PPO2 protein phase transition
item.dc:creator: Mingyu Shin
Eunji Chang
Daewon Lee
Nayun Kim
Bumsik Cho
Nuri Cha
Ferdinand Koranteng
Ji-Joon Song
Jiwon Shim

item.title: Terahertz phonon engineering with van der Waals heterostructures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07604-9

In an application of terahertz phonon engineering, terahertz phonons were generated, detected and manipulated through precise integration of atomically thin layers in van der Waals heterostructures.
item.dc:title: Terahertz phonon engineering with van der Waals heterostructures
item.dc:creator: Yoseob Yoon
Zheyu Lu

item.title: Observations of diapycnal upwelling within a sloping submarine canyon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07411-2

A dye-release experiment within a sloping submarine canyon provides direct evidence that vigorous mixing at topographic features, such as canyons, leads to rapid diapycnal upwelling of deep water.
item.dc:title: Observations of diapycnal upwelling within a sloping submarine canyon
item.dc:creator: Bethan L. Wynne-Cattanach
Nicole Couto
Henri F. Drake
Raffaele Ferrari

Matthew H. Alford

item.title: Does Ozempic boost fertility? What the science says
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02045-w

Blockbuster weight-loss drugs have been linked to unexplained pregnancies. Research shows it is plausible, but more data is needed.
item.dc:title: Does Ozempic boost fertility? What the science says
item.dc:creator: Gillian Dohrn

item.title: Powerful laser miniaturized from tabletop to microchip
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01646-9

Lasers are essential in scientific laboratories and medical clinics across the globe, but integrating them into other technologies is not easy. A material platform that puts a standard laser on a microchip offers a solution.
item.dc:title: Powerful laser miniaturized from tabletop to microchip
item.dc:creator: Ajanta Barh

item.title: Is science’s dominant funding model broken?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02080-7

Should one principal investigator have the power to determine postdocs’ careers? Share your thoughts on academia’s dominant funding model in our survey and reader poll.
item.dc:title: Is science’s dominant funding model broken?

item.title: Controlled stacking of boron nitride layers for ferroelectric memory applications
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02111-3

Rhombohedral boron nitride films have a unique combination of properties that make them desirable in electronic and optical applications. An innovative method can be used to create particularly promising large-scale single crystals, bringing the films much closer to real-world applications.
item.dc:title: Controlled stacking of boron nitride layers for ferroelectric memory applications

item.title: Flies use blood cells to take a deep breath
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01649-6

Insect respiration is commonly thought to rely solely on direct gas exchange through air-filled tracheal tubes. The discovery of oxygen-transporting blood cells in fly larvae reveals a previously unknown way to oxygenate fly tissues.
item.dc:title: Flies use blood cells to take a deep breath
item.dc:creator: Stefan Luschnig

item.title: How the grid came to shape the US landscape
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02083-4

Science and reason underpinned early surveys, but sociopolitical ideals left their mark on the nation too, a historical account concludes.
item.dc:title: How the grid came to shape the US landscape
item.dc:creator: K. John Holmes

item.title: How to network with the brightest minds in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02086-1

Past attendees of the Lindau Nobel Laureate meeting describe how the event can benefit early career researchers.
item.dc:title: How to network with the brightest minds in science
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: Deep-sea dye confirms turbulent-mixing theory — with implications for climate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01647-8

Carbon storage in Earth’s oceans is controlled by deep-sea mixing processes, but the details have proved difficult to test. Ambitious efforts to track ocean mixing using dye have now demonstrated the pivotal role of the sea floor.
item.dc:title: Deep-sea dye confirms turbulent-mixing theory — with implications for climate
item.dc:creator: Ryan M. Holmes

item.title: How I’m using AI tools to help universities maximize research impacts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02081-6

Artificial-intelligence algorithms could identify scientists who need support with translating their work into real-world applications and more. Leaders must step up.
item.dc:title: How I’m using AI tools to help universities maximize research impacts
item.dc:creator: Dashun Wang

item.title: What it means to be a successful male academic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02105-1

Prioritizing family life has earned me respect in my field — and my research has improved, too, says Dritjon Gruda.
item.dc:title: What it means to be a successful male academic
item.dc:creator: Dritjon Gruda

item.title: Programmable RNA-guided enzymes for next-generation genome editing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01461-2

RNA-guided recombinase enzymes have been discovered that herald a new chapter for genome editing — enabling the insertion, inversion or deletion of long DNA sequences at user-specified genome positions.
item.dc:title: Programmable RNA-guided enzymes for next-generation genome editing
item.dc:creator: Connor J. Tou
Benjamin P. Kleinstiver

item.title: These 3D model brains with cells from several people are first of their kind
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02096-z

Chimeric brain ‘organoids’ promise to help reveal individual variation in brain development and in drug responses.
item.dc:title: These 3D model brains with cells from several people are first of their kind
item.dc:creator: Asher Mullard

item.title: Estonians gave their DNA to science — now they’re learning their genetic secrets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02108-y

Project covering one-fifth of the country’s population is one of the largest-ever efforts to share results on genetic health risks with research participants.
item.dc:title: Estonians gave their DNA to science — now they’re learning their genetic secrets
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Ms Anaria’s classroom rules for <Emphasis Type="Strikethrough">well-behaved kindergartners</Emphasis> when alien ambassadors dock with the wrong ship
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02075-4

Every day is a school day.
item.dc:title: Ms Anaria’s classroom rules for <Emphasis Type="Strikethrough">well-behaved kindergartners</Emphasis> when alien ambassadors dock with the wrong ship
item.dc:creator: Catherine Tavares

item.title: UK general election: five reasons it matters for science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02110-4

Visa rules, funding and evolving net-zero targets are among scientists’ concerns as UK citizens prepare to vote next week.
item.dc:title: UK general election: five reasons it matters for science
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O'Callaghan
Elizabeth Gibney

item.title: Chimeric brain organoids capture human genetic diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01648-7

Models of the human brain’s cortex have been made by combining cells from up to five donors. This approach could enable genetic background to be accounted for in studies of brain development and disease.
item.dc:title: Chimeric brain organoids capture human genetic diversity
item.dc:creator: Aparna Bhaduri

item.title: ‘Vindicated’: Embattled misinformation researchers celebrate key US Supreme Court decision
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01766-2

The justices rule that the US government can keep talking to scientists and social-media firms with the aim of curbing falsehoods online.
item.dc:title: ‘Vindicated’: Embattled misinformation researchers celebrate key US Supreme Court decision
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: The science of protests: how to shape public opinion and swing votes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02082-5

Demonstrations are on the rise, and scientists are revealing which types work best.
item.dc:title: The science of protests: how to shape public opinion and swing votes
item.dc:creator: Helen Pearson

item.title: Mini saunas save endangered frogs from fungal disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01650-z

Amphibian species around the world are threatened with extinction by the deadly fungal disease chytridiomycosis. A simple, low-cost solution to provide warm conditions enables frogs to clear the infection and remain disease free.
item.dc:title: Mini saunas save endangered frogs from fungal disease
item.dc:creator: Brian Gratwicke
Anna Savage

item.title: Spongy but not glassy: Ediacaran fossil provides insight into early animal evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02033-0

Sea sponges were among the first animals to evolve. But, perplexingly, they left few early fossils despite having dense yet porous bodies. The Ediacaran fossil Helicolocellus cantori is interpreted as having been a glass sponge without biomineralized spicules (little spikes made of glass) to support its body.
item.dc:title: Spongy but not glassy: Ediacaran fossil provides insight into early animal evolution

item.title: See how your body works in real time — wearable ultrasound is on its way
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02066-5

Full-body, continuous wearable ultrasound will benefit health care and biomedical research. Seven key obstacles must first be overcome.
item.dc:title: See how your body works in real time — wearable ultrasound is on its way
item.dc:creator: Chonghe Wang
Xuanhe Zhao

item.title: The strategy behind one of the most successful labs in the world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02085-2

One UK institute has produced a dozen Nobel laureates and biomedical breakthroughs across the board. How does Cambridge’s Laboratory of Molecular Biology do it? Our study found out.
item.dc:title: The strategy behind one of the most successful labs in the world
item.dc:creator: Luka Gebel
Chander Velu
Antonio Vidal-Puig

item.title: Why ‘open source’ AIs could be anything but, the derailment risks of long freight trains, and breeding better wheat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02120-2

We round up some recent stories from the Nature Briefing.
item.dc:title: Why ‘open source’ AIs could be anything but, the derailment risks of long freight trains, and breeding better wheat
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Benjamin Thompson
Dan Fox

item.title: Families given cash with no strings spend more money on kids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02097-y

Monthly cash transfers reduce risk of poverty — and higher amounts do not lead to higher spending on tobacco or alcohol.
item.dc:title: Families given cash with no strings spend more money on kids

item.title: Galapagos battles goats and tourists in 1974
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02088-z

Imports threaten the natural environment of Darwin’s favourite islands, and a reader ponders the longevity of carps, in the weekly dip into Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: Galapagos battles goats and tourists in 1974

item.title: How researchers navigate a PhD later in life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02109-x

Personal circumstances and commitments often add to the pressures faced by older graduate students. Nature sought advice from some who have risen to the challenge.
item.dc:title: How researchers navigate a PhD later in life
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Landau

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Polar rain aurora’ seen from Earth for the first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02117-x

Scientists got the first-ever unimpeded view from Earth of a rare aurora spanning more than 3,000 kilometres across the North Pole. Plus, ‘fantastic’ particle could be the most energetic neutrino ever detected and why extreme wildfires are now more common.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Polar rain aurora’ seen from Earth for the first time
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: Tech giants are ‘open-washing’ their AI models
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02122-0

Google, Microsoft and others are describing their AI models as open source while disclosing little key information. Plus, self-driving cars’ safety record remains unclear and a new word for chatbot confabulations.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: Tech giants are ‘open-washing’ their AI models
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: First ever rocks from the Moon’s far side have landed on Earth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02101-5

Scientists are eager to work on Chang’e-6 rock samples, which touched down in the Chinese autonomous region Inner Mongolia today.

item.dc:creator: Ling Xin

item.content:encoded:

item.dc:title: ‘Fantastic’ particle could be most energetic neutrino ever detected
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: The last few miles: how to prepare for the late-career stage in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02093-2

It can be daunting to see the final chapter of your career approaching. Planning ahead can help.
item.dc:title: The last few miles: how to prepare for the late-career stage in science
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Open-washing’ plagues big AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02103-3

Open-source artificial intelligence is nowhere near as open as its name would suggest, low-frequency vibrations arouse genital nerve cells in mice and why we must put people at the heart of schizophrenia research.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Open-washing’ plagues big AI
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Gut microbiome discovery provides roadmap for life-saving cancer therapies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-02070-9

The balance between bacterial communities in the gut affects the likelihood of a positive response to drugs called checkpoint inhibitors.
item.dc:title: Gut microbiome discovery provides roadmap for life-saving cancer therapies
item.dc:creator: Giorgia Guglielmi
